Taylor Farms Colorado Springs, Colorado Risk Management Plan
Executive Summary

The Taylor Farms Colorado Springs facility is newly built and is a producer of ready-to-eat salads.  Taylor Farms has implemented a Process Safety Management program to comply with OSHA regulations and the Risk Management Plan in compliance with the EPA.

Senior Management Commitment

Taylor Farms is committed to safety and allocates resources to accomplish safety goals, for example:

Purchasing safety equipment; hiring a consultant for assistance with safety and environmental matters, conducting safety training for managers, supervisors and employees.

Taylor Farms Ammonia Refrigeration System 

The refrigeration system is operated by a trained contract ammonia technician and 2 in-house operators.  The system is regularly monitored, inspected and maintained.  The refrigeration department utilizes preventative maintenance, standard operating procedures, regular and frequent inspections and safety programs.  

Safety procedures include: lockout tagout, hot work permit, hazard communication, ammonia safety, respiratory protection, contractor control, opening system permits, hearing protection, fire prevention and protection, hazardous waste disposal, emergency response and maintenance procedures to ensure the safe operation of the refrigeration system.

The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

The facility is covered under OSHA 29 CFR 1910.110 Process Safety Management and EPA 40 Part 68 Risk Management Plan for having more than 10,000 pounds of Anhydrous Ammonia.  The release prevention measures and activities are detailed in the PSM program.  In addition, an ammonia refrigeration contractor is utilized to provide maintenance support, improvements and additional maintenance activities beyond the plantA?s capabilities as needed.

The PSM program has been designed to address the requirements of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Final Rule 1910.119, "Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals." The company has designed and structured its PSM program to conform to current Safety and Health Policies, training programs, employee participation practices, vendor-supplied equipment operating and maintenance procedures, and current management policies and practices, and to eliminate excessive rework of existing safe practices.  The Process Safety Management program is structured to address future requirements also.

The PSM program includes existing procedures and practices whenever practical and appropriate.  The complete PSM program ensures comp

rehensive coverage of process areas handling anhydrous ammonia and application of process safety controls.

The concept of Process Safety Management has its roots in solid management practices developed in various process industries.  Management systems are a structured, systematic method to implement an identified set of activities with assigned responsibilities to achieve desired results.  The management systems combined into a PSM program providing organization and application of controls, policies, practices, and procedures.

PSM Process and Facility Overview

The facility operates an ammonia refrigeration system to produce space cooling, product cooling, and process equipment cooling.

The refrigeration system is designed to provide:

A?operating flexibility;
A?economy and efficiency of operations;
A?optimal safety performance; and
A?consistency of operation, utilizing programmable logic controllers (PLCs) to monitor, record, operate, and modulate refrigeration equipment as conditions require.

Emergency Response Program

The facility has an emergency response program reviewed with the Colorado Springs Haz-Mat Dept Inspector.
